title.narrative: OUTP 4.4: NUTRITION EMERGENCY PREP. ANDRESPONSE

description.narrative: Strengthened capacity for preparedness, implementation, coordination and monitoring of nutrition response targeting most vulnerable boys, girls and women in humanitarian situations, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 4: Infants, young children and mothers have increased and equitable use of nutritional services and improved nutrition and care practices, with a focus on stunting.

MINISTRY OF HEALTH AND CHILD CARE

sector.narrative: Capacity building for nutrition preparedness and response
Care for children with severe acute malnutrition
Diet diversity in early childhood (children under 5), includes complementary feeding and MNPs
Technical assistance - Prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Strengthened capacity for preparedness, implementation, coordination and monitoring of nutrition response targeting mostvulnerable boys, girls and women in humanitarian situations

description.narrative: UNICEF as cluster lead for Nutrition coordinated all nutrition response activities implemented by government and implementing partners. Monitoring data was collected using RapidPro, analyzed and reported through DHIS2. ;Of the 13,800 children targeted for treatment of severe wasting, 11,079 children (6,226 girls and 4,853 boys)- 80%, were successfully treated with a 73% cure rate. UNICEF supplied nutrition commodities to all health facilities and 93% of the health facilities had no stock-outs of RUTF throughout the year. Vitamin A supplementation coverage in the 32 emergency response districts was 96% (398,047). | Status:On-track | As-of Date:11/01/2022
